title: Lancaut Walk Route

images.title: Philip Halling / Lancaut and the Lancaut Peninsula, the Wye Valley
images.caption: Lancaut and the Lancaut Peninsula, the Wye Valley. The farm at Lancaut, which appears to be undergoing conversion or development, viewpoint from the popular viewpoint of the Eagle's Neat above Wyndcliff. The River Wye can be seen in the background.

images.title: Old church ruins at Lancaut by Jeremy Bolwell, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: St James's Church, Lancaut. Lancaut takes its name from Llan (Welsh for church) and an obscure Welsh saint, named Cewydd. The origins of this small church date from the 12th century, however, the church was abandoned in 1840 and has been roofless since 1865. It is located is a secluded spot in the Wye Valley. The cliffs in the background are Wintour's Leap.

images.caption: River Wye from Woodcroft

images.title: Chris Heaton / Organic Field, Tutshill
images.caption: Organic Field, Tutshill. Field specially put aside for organic matters, giving a wonderful spread of wild flowers. The Offa's Dyke follows the eastern boundary

images.title: WFan, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Chepstow castle

description: This walk explores the Lancaut Peninsula in the Wye Valley AONB. It's a scenic and historic place situated around the abandoned medieval village of Lancaut. The area includes a pleasant riverside walk and some interesting old ruined buildings including the ancient Lancaut Church. The trail runs for about 2 miles from Lancaut to Chepstow, passing the 12th century Lancaut church ruins, Woodcroft Quarry and the wonderful viewpoint at Wintour's Leap on the way. The route finishes in Chepstow where you can visit the historic castle. Lancaut is also a designated nature reserve so there's lots of birdlife and interesting flora to see on the way. Keep your eyes peeled for peregrine falcon, raven,  cormorant and herons in the river area.
